pr_title: Add PRT storage support for MSAL-CPP

timeline.bodyText: At a glance, this doesn't look correct.... IIRC RefreshToken credential types set "" as the realm, my suspicion is that PRTs should be cached according to the same rules. This should be confirmed with the iOS team for consistency
timeline.author: iambmelt

replies.bodyText: Thanks. Changed REALM to "". And also do we need to set client_id to "" as well for PRT ?
replies.author: richard1122

replies.bodyText: @richard1122 please confirm the desired cache-key behavior with @oldalton and write your tests accordingly
replies.author: iambmelt

timeline.bodyText: nit: the format, as I understand it, will be something like "3.0", not "V3"
timeline.author: iambmelt
iambmelt

timeline.bodyText: Hi @jbzdarkid, could you help review this?
timeline.author: richard1122

replies.bodyText: Can you explain what part of this wasn't working? I saw no issues with evaluateJavascript in the tests that Brian & I ran.
replies.author: jbzdarkid

replies.bodyText:
In the WIP PR to enable InteractivePrtApiTests: https://github.com/AzureAD/microsoft-authentication-library-for-cpp/pull/1836/files#diff-a8ca4d4dabdc4dd14163d2252bf0d0f7db2cdf9bc7627e2e7c4dd61a7a6b09adR269
The webview will stuck at signin page, and after connected devtools, I saw endless requests canceled. Added some captures.
https://identitydivision.visualstudio.com/DevEx/_workitems/edit/1268511/
replies.author: richard1122

timeline.bodyText:
Hi @oldalton, this is cache key for PRT.
Now it only constructed from HOME_ACCOUNT_ID, ENVIRONMENT and CREDENTIAL_TYPE.
Tests add primaryRefreshTokenCacheKeyComplete
timeline.author: richard1122

replies.bodyText:
Hi, please follow the schema as described here: https://identitydivision.visualstudio.com/DevEx/_git/AuthLibrariesApiReview?path=%2FSSO%2FSchema.md (Primary refresh token schema section)
Key should contain home account id, environment, credential type, and clientId in a specific order.
replies.author: oldalton

replies.bodyText: Thanks, please help review again..
replies.author: richard1122

timeline.bodyText: I don't understand this. Why is this value being set to ""? Can you point me towards where this is outlined in the schema spec?
timeline.author: iambmelt

replies.bodyText: OK -  I believe this comes from here - can you please update the implementation of AbstractAccountCredentialCache#getCredentialsFilteredByInternal() to ensure this is handled correctly when filtering serialized records? It looks like PRT lookups need to behave like wildcards when filtering by realm and target. See uses of mustMatchOnRealm and mustMatchOnTarget
replies.author: iambmelt

replies.bodyText: Just looked mustMatchOnTarget, mustMatchOnRealm, it works as wildcard for PRT.
replies.author: richard1122

replies.bodyText: Also updated mustMatchOnClientId to not filter by client_id for PRT, and added two tests.
replies.author: richard1122

replies.bodyText:
Also updated mustMatchOnClientId to not filter by client_id for PRT, and added two tests.

@richard1122 I no longer see these changes in this PR. Not needed?
replies.author: iambmelt

replies.bodyText: Hi @iambmelt , from discussion here, we will continue support filter by client id, and let caller decide.
replies.author: richard1122

replies.bodyText: ACK, resolved
replies.author: iambmelt

timeline.bodyText: Same here.... I don't understand this. Why is this value being set to ""? Can you point me towards where this is outlined in the schema spec?
timeline.author: iambmelt

replies.bodyText: OK - I think is same as here, please see this comment re: updating filter logic used for serialized instances
replies.author: iambmelt

timeline.bodyText: What is meant here by "reversed"? This naming unclear to me
timeline.author: iambmelt

replies.bodyText:
It's typo. Updated to RESERVED_PRT_CLIENT_ID.
Just like windows code
replies.author: richard1122

replies.bodyText: Should we use the actual clientId that you're using for PRT acquisition?
replies.author: oldalton

replies.bodyText:
Should we use the actual clientId that you're using for PRT acquisition?

Same question
replies.author: iambmelt

replies.bodyText: We can change it, but then we'd have to update code on other platforms too. I don't know if we want to make that step before we have to.
replies.author: jbzdarkid

replies.bodyText: (It looks like this is by-design: is it documented though?)
replies.author: iambmelt

replies.bodyText: I have no idea. It's same as windows code. Let me know your decision.
replies.author: richard1122
iambmelt

replies.bodyText: I agree - we use real broker clientId in iOS and macOS broker as well for PRT storage, so this is inconsistent with it. However, if it would be a breaking SSO change and it doesn't conflict with other PRT storages, then agree with @jbzdarkid that we might not want to do it. If it's not a breaking SSO change though, let's make the change now rather than after we ship.
replies.author: oldalton

replies.bodyText:
OK, so we are going to:

Save real client id in cache key
Fetch by real client id or (wildcard -- any), caller decide

I'll make the change and update tests.
replies.author: richard1122

replies.bodyText: Update, please help review, thanks !
replies.author: richard1122

timeline.bodyText:
Could we instead move this logic 'up' such that its more like
final boolean mustMatchOnClientId = !StringExtensions.isNullOrBlank(clientId) && !(credential instanceof PrimaryRefreshTokenRecord) ;
timeline.author: iambmelt

replies.bodyText: Thanks, updated.
replies.author: richard1122

timeline.bodyText:
This now appears unused... do we need a property to track the realm? If not, can this be removed?
It would be great to understand whether the PRT needs to be associated with a realm

Fundamentally, it has a realm component of its cache key, but its always "" -- can we safely assume we will never need to lookup a PRT by realm?
timeline.author: iambmelt

replies.author: richard1122

replies.bodyText: Deleted
replies.author: richard1122

timeline.bodyText: Can this be a value class? We'd (potentially) have to write an InstanceCreator, but we wouldn't need to worry about those setter methods, nor about making sure anything using it was properly synchronized w.r.t. creation.
timeline.author: AdamBJohnsonx

+package com.microsoft.identity.common.internal.dto;
+
+import com.google.gson.annotations.SerializedName;
+
+import java.util.Calendar;
+import java.util.Date;
+import java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit;
+
+import static com.microsoft.identity.common.internal.dto.PrimaryRefreshTokenRecord.SerializedNames.*;
+
+public class PrimaryRefreshTokenRecord extends Credential {
+
+    public static class SerializedNames extends Credential.SerializedNames {
+        /**
+         * String of family id.
+         */
+        public static final String FAMILY_ID = "family_id";
+
+        /**
+         * String of session_key.
+         */
+        public static final String SESSION_KEY = "session_key";
+
+        /**
+         * String of session_key_rolling_date.
+         */
+        public static final String SESSION_KEY_ROLLING_DATE = "session_key_rolling_date";
+
+        /**
+         * String of prt_protocol_version.
+         */
+        public static final String PRT_PROTOCOL_VERSION = "prt_protocol_version";
+    }
+
+    /**
+     * 1st Party Application Family ID.
+     */
+    @SerializedName(FAMILY_ID)
+    private String mFamilyId;
+
+    /**
+     * PRT expiry time. This value is returned from the server as refresh_token_expires_in that
+     * should be added to local time.
+     */
+    @SerializedName(EXPIRES_ON)
+    private String mExpiresOn;
+
+    /**
+     * Session key of PRT.
+     */
+    @SerializedName(SESSION_KEY)
+    private String mSessionKey;
+
+    /**
+     * The version of the PRT Protocol being used, version 3 supports no device_id.
+     */
+    @SerializedName(PRT_PROTOCOL_VERSION)
+    private String mPrtProtocolVersion;
+
+    /**
+     * Session key expiry time. This value is determined by the client and set to 60 days after the
+     * session key was initally issued
+     */
+    @SerializedName(SESSION_KEY_ROLLING_DATE)
+    private String mSessionKeyRollingDate;
+
+    /**
+     * Gets the family_id.
+     *
+     * @return The family_id to get.
+     */
+    public String getFamilyId() {
+        return mFamilyId;
+    }
+
+    /**
+     * Sets the family_id.
+     *
+     * @param familyId The family_id to set.
+     */
+    public void setFamilyId(final String familyId) {
+        mFamilyId = familyId;
+    }
+
+    public boolean isExpired(final String expires) {
+        // Init a Calendar for the current time/date
+        final Calendar calendar = Calendar.getInstance();
+        final Date validity = calendar.getTime();
+        // Init a Date for the accessToken's expiry
+        long epoch = Long.valueOf(expires);
+        final Date expiresOn = new Date(
+                TimeUnit.SECONDS.toMillis(epoch)
+        );
+        return expiresOn.before(validity);

replies.bodyText: Updated, thanks

+         */

+
+        /**

+         */

+        /**
+         * String of prt_protocol_version.
+         */
+        public static final String PRT_PROTOCOL_VERSION = "prt_protocol_version";

+    /**

+     */
+    @SerializedName(EXPIRES_ON)

+
+    /**
+     * Session key of PRT.

+    @SerializedName(SESSION_KEY)

+
+    /**

+    @SerializedName(PRT_PROTOCOL_VERSION)

+
+    /**

+    @SerializedName(SESSION_KEY_ROLLING_DATE)

+    /**

replies.bodyText: It's same as AccessTokenRecord, we can just leave it?
replies.author: richard1122

replies.bodyText: Eh.  I'd like to change it everywhere, if I could.  Since it's a String, it doesn't tell the developer anything about what's in it - for all a programmer knows without looking at the implementation it's an ISO date string.  Not a huge issue, just something that could be better.
replies.author: AdamBJohnsonx

timeline.bodyText: @jbzdarkid Hi, I keep your evaluateJavascript here. It should not cause test unstable. I'll try more after this PR merged.
timeline.author: richard1122

replies.bodyText: <3 Thank you, I'm happy to help you with investigation if you need.
replies.author: jbzdarkid

timeline.bodyText: Auth scheme shouldn't apply here -- please confirm this test passes with null as its param as well. This criteria doesn't apply to PRTs
timeline.author: iambmelt

replies.bodyText: Thanks, deleted.
replies.author: richard1122

timeline.bodyText: Same here - scheme should only apply to ATs
timeline.author: iambmelt

replies.bodyText: Thanks, deleted.
replies.author: richard1122

timeline.bodyText: Let's include the format of this value. I'm guessing it's probably epoch seconds? Would be good to have this info in the javadoc
timeline.author: iambmelt

+     * PRT expiry time. This value is returned from the server as refresh_token_expires_in that
+     * should be added to local time.

+    @SerializedName(EXPIRES_ON)
+    private String mExpiresOn;

+    /**
+     * Session key of PRT.
+     */
+    @SerializedName(SESSION_KEY)
+    private String mSessionKey;
+

+    @SerializedName(PRT_PROTOCOL_VERSION)
+    private String mPrtProtocolVersion;
+
+    /**
+     * Session key expiry time. This value is determined by the client and set to 60 days after the
+     * session key was initally issued
+     */
+    @SerializedName(SESSION_KEY_ROLLING_DATE)
+    private String mSessionKeyRollingDate;
+
+    /**

+        return Long.parseLong(expirationTimeEpochSeconds) * 1000 < System.currentTimeMillis();

replies.bodyText: It's kind-of less important because the broker should never be able to read this cache and <->.  I'd prefer to handle these keys as an interface that doesn't ever expose the key material to a cavalier user rather than as the key itself, but that detail will be in the cpp code review.
